unnormalised: Ensuring robust quality control is paramount for competing in today's global market. Experts at IIT Madras emphasized at a workshop on 10/10/2024 that implementing Six Sigma principles, adapted to the Indian context, can dramatically reduce defects. This involves rigorous testing at each stage, from sourcing raw materials like steel from Bhilai to final product assembly in factories near Chennai.

unnormalised: Companies like Tata Steel are investing heavily in automated inspection systems. Proper documentation, as per ISO 9001 standards, is crucial. Forget ‘chalta hai’ attitude! Poor quality can impact brand reputation and consumer trust, costing companies lakhs of rupees in recalls. The Ministry of Commerce is expected to release new guidelines on 26/01/2025 (Republic Day) to further improve quality standards across various sectors. This includes detailed checklists and standardized testing procedures ensuring the 'Made in India' tag truly signifies superior quality.
